claims.text: Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
The 1.5 degrees Celsius target was written into the 2015 Paris Agreement.
Earth's weather cycles are becoming increasingly erratic, severe, and prolonged.
Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
The 1.5 degrees Celsius target was written into the 2015 Paris Agreement.
Earth's weather cycles are becoming increasingly erratic, severe, and prolonged.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources consistently indicates that human-induced global warming is a major factor in changing weather patterns, leading to increased intensity of droughts, wildfires, and extreme rainfall, as well as shifts in precipitation patterns.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human-induced global warming is causing significant changes in weather patterns, including increased intensity of droughts, wildfires, and extreme rainfall, as well as shifts in precipitation patterns across different regions.
supports.snippet: Human activities, principally through emissions of greenhouse gases, have unequivocally caused global warming, with global surface temperature ...

supports.title: The Effects of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human-induced global warming is causing significant changes in weather patterns, including increased intensity of droughts, wildfires, and extreme rainfall, as well as shifts in precipitation patterns across different regions.
supports.snippet: We already see effects scientists predicted, such as the loss of sea ice, melting glaciers and ice sheets, sea level rise, and more intense heat ...

supports.title: How Climate Change Is Fueling Extreme Weather - Earthjustice
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that human-induced global warming is significantly affecting weather patterns, leading to more extreme weather events such as droughts, wildfires, and intense rainfall. It emphasizes that these changes are already occurring and will worsen with continued greenhouse gas emissions.
supports.snippet: Human activity is causing rapid changes to our global climate that are contributing to extreme weather conditions.

supports.title: Human Impacts on the Environment: A Focus on Climate Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human-induced global warming is a major factor in changing weather patterns, as it details how increased greenhouse gas emissions from human activities are causing widespread environmental changes, including altered precipitation patterns, intensified droughts, and increased storm intensity.
supports.snippet: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The 1.5 degrees Celsius target was written into the 2015 Paris Agreement.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources, including the UNFCCC and IPCC, confirms that the 1.5 degrees Celsius target was explicitly included in the 2015 Paris Agreement, where countries committed to limit global warming to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1.5°C.

supports.title: The Paris Agreement | UNFCCC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the 1.5 degrees Celsius target was indeed included in the 2015 Paris Agreement, as countries agreed to limit global warming to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1.5°C.
supports.snippet: To limit global warming to 1.5°C, greenhouse gas emissions must peak before 2025 at the latest and decline 43% by 2030.

supports.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Paris Agreement includes a commitment to limit global warming to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1.5°C, thus validating the claim that the 1.5 degrees Celsius target was written into the agreement.
supports.snippet: An IPCC special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways.

supports.title: Paris temperature goal - Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the 1.5 degrees Celsius target was indeed included in the Paris Agreement, as countries agreed to limit global warming to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit it to 1.5°C.
supports.snippet: The 1.5°C Paris Agreement goal is, by design, a strengthening of the Cancun 2°C goal. The origin of the 1.5°C Paris Agreement limit derived from the concern ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Earth's weather cycles are becoming increasingly erratic, severe, and prolonged.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that Earth's weather cycles are becoming increasingly erratic, severe, and prolonged. Multiple high-reliability sources, including reports from NASA and the WMO, indicate record-breaking temperatures and an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heat waves and floods.

supports.title: Charting the Exceptional, Unexpected Heat of 2023 and 2024
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the record-breaking global temperatures in 2023 and 2024, indicating an unexpected intensity and prolonged duration of heat, which aligns with the claim of increasingly erratic and severe weather cycles.
supports.snippet: The charts on this page show how much global temperatures in 2023 and 2024 diverged from expectations based on NASA's temperature record.

supports.title: Climate change indicators reached record levels in 2023: WMO
supports.evidence_summary: The WMO report indicates that 2023 was the warmest year on record, suggesting a trend of increasing temperatures that can contribute to erratic and severe weather patterns.
supports.snippet: The WMO report confirmed that 2023 was the warmest year on record, with the global average near-surface temperature at 1.45 °Celsius.

supports.title: Extreme weather - World Meteorological Organization WMO
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heat waves, floods, and droughts, which supports the claim that Earth's weather cycles are becoming more erratic and severe.
supports.snippet: More frequent and more intense weather events, such as severe heatwaves, and heavy precipitation lead to increased impacts on more vulnerable populations.

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heat waves, floods, and droughts, which supports the claim that Earth's weather cycles are becoming more erratic and severe.
supports.snippet: As Earth's climate changes, it is impacting extreme weather across the planet. Record-breaking heat waves on land and in the ocean, drenching rains, severe ...

supports.title: Chapter 11: Weather and Climate Extreme Events in a Changing ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heat waves, floods, and droughts, which supports the claim that Earth's weather cycles are becoming more erratic and severe.
supports.snippet: This chapter assesses changes in weather and climate extremes on regional and global scales, including observed changes and their attribution, as well as ...

supports.title: Climate Change Made Summer 2023 One for the Record Books
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the record-breaking global temperatures in 2023 and 2024, indicating that the intensity and duration of heat events are becoming more extreme, which aligns with the claim about erratic and severe weather cycles.
supports.snippet: Summer 2023 was the hottest on record, and by a “large margin”, scientists confirmed. Temperatures in June were 0.5C above the 1991-2020 average.

transcript_data.text: from flooding to heat waves wildfires to droughts our planet has been experiencing more frequent and intense weather events in recent years so how is this connected to climate change and how can we lessen its impact this is decomplicated how is extreme weather connected to climate change Earth's weather Cycles have shown signs of becoming increasingly more erratic severe and prolonged and though there is no blanket explanation for this change of weather patterns human-induced global warming is a major underlying Factor increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released such as carbon dioxide and methane into Earth's atmosphere this has contributed to climate change in the form of increased global temperatures which can then affect How likely and how intense an extreme weather event can be the causality between global climate change and individual extreme weather event varies from event to event based on the type of weather the location time of year and how intense widespread and long it is however not all events are becoming more likely and severe some may be decreased in Chance by climate change or may not be changed much and changes are irregular across the world foreign what are some examples of extreme weather there are four main examples of extreme weather heat waves wildfires droughts and increased rainfall heat waves in many parts of the world are getting hotter more frequent and lasting longer and this is a result of human cause climate change hot spells have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years and it's estimated that heat waves are 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office increased heat has contributed to more regular and extensive Wildfire seasons in some areas of all continents this is because more moisture is drawn out of the earth and vegetation by more frequent and intense heat waves this then provides ideal kindling conditions for wildfires human activities such as Forest management and ignition sources are also important causal factors for these events droughts are becoming more common and more severe in some areas due to climate change there are two main ways this happens firstly through evaporation as the atmosphere warms more evaporation from the land occurs secondly through rainfall individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world falling in shorter and more intense bursts this heavier rain is more likely to saturate the ground and run directly into rivers rather than sustaining soil moisture and groundwater Reserve during more moderate rainfall overall the combination of more evaporation more sporadic heavier rainfall and less average downpours make dry spells more common in drought prone regions and seasons droughts put added pressure on Water Supplies as demand increases from people in agriculture which can lead to shortages human Water Management can also impact the likelihood of droughts increased rainfall has affected most of the world due to human-course climate change typically hot weather creates moisture and water vapor in the air which turns into droplets to create rain the warmer it becomes the more Vapor there is in the atmosphere this results in more droplets and heavier rainfall sometimes in a shorter space of time and over a small area this increased rainfall worsens flooding which can damage infrastructure and contaminate groundwater making it unsafe to drink however flooding can also be caused by human factors such as water management and defenses how can we lessen this impact scientists and experts have warned that if we want to reduce the worst consequences of climate breakdown we need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius this target was written into the 2015 Paris agreement a legally binding treaty that 196 parties agreed to uphold the goal is to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius preferably to 1.5 degrees celsius compared to pre-industrial levels this Baseline was partly chosen because it's the earliest period with near Global observations in order to keep temperatures under 1.5 degrees Celsius dramatic changes need to be made namely Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 Levels by 2030 and at Net Zero or as close to no total carbon emissions as possible by 2050. the 1.5 degrees Celsius Target is increasingly Moving Out Of Reach an extreme weather is continuing to become more frequent and prevalent globally these multiple climate impacts will likely worsen a host of issues people around the world are currently facing like food insecurity damaged infrastructure induced migration and constrained resources however there is still hope that we can minimize the destructive cycles of extreme weather but in order to do so we must focus on limiting any further human impact on our Global Climate immediately [Music]
